comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This is a pic of the Petrie Bight reach of the Brisbane River. bishop.slq.qld.gov.au/view/action/singleViewer.do?dvs=137... link to a pic of the Thomas Brown & Sons warehouse...not sure when it became known as the Thomas Brown & Sons warehouse etc...possibly from 1898 adb.anu.edu.au/biography/brown-david-laughland-3073

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I gather that the Thomas Brown & Sons warehouse which we see here was built on the site of the D.L Brown & Co warehouse, which burned down in September 1888... nla.gov.au/nla.news-article84132029 I haven't found a firm date for the construction of the new warehouse, but I'd guess the site might have been a hole in the ground for a good few months after the fire...and that the new warehouse was built in ca. 1889-1890... bishop.slq.qld.gov.au/view/action/singleViewer.do?dvs=137... ...all up, the old and new Brown warehouses in Eagle St should be good date markers for pics of this reach of the Brisbane River. The new building was evidently designed by architect F.D.G. Stanley (1839-1896) www.pillarsofanation.com.au/architects6.html If that cupola is at the Central Fire Station at the corner of Ann & Wharf Sts, then this pic is a bit later than I initially thought...need to find dates for a few more buildings...work in progress

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Thanks quasymody! Lovely research as usual. The only info we had on this image was that it was taken by John Cameron from an original Poulsen negative, who apparently was a real estate agent in Cleveland, Brisbane. John Cameron died in 1910, thanks to this information via Redland City Council.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
